study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore associations between acculturation and physical activity, including leisure walking, among Latina breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: Greater acculturation was associated with higher levels of leisure walking at moderate-to-vigorous intensity (265.8 vs 179.0 min/wk). However, acculturation was also linked to poorer diet quality and higher central obesity.
population_specificity: Latina women (n=167) residing in New York City with a history of stage 0 to III breast cancer, no recurrent/metastatic disease, and at least 90 days post-treatment.
study_duration: Not specified (baseline data from a randomized controlled trial conducted between July 2016 and October 2018)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a supervised acute physical exercise session prior to immune-chemotherapy infusion and an unsupervised home-walking program in patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (mNSCLC).
results_summary: The study is at the pre-results stage, so no specific findings on Walking's effects are reported yet. The abstract outlines the study design and planned assessments of clinical, physical, biological, and psychosocial parameters.
population_specificity: Patients newly diagnosed with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (mNSCLC).
effective_dosage: 35-minute interval training at submaximal intensity prior to immune-chemotherapy infusion, plus an unsupervised home-based walking program with an activity tracker.
study_duration: 3 months for the exercise program, with assessments at baseline, 3, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze risk factors, including walking difficulties, for venous thrombosis following spine surgery.
results_summary: The study found that walking issues, along with other factors like age, blood loss, and comorbidities, were associated with an increased risk of venous thrombosis after spinal surgery.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent spine surgery (1,927,781 individuals, including 7,843 with venous thrombosis).

study_goal: To assess the attainment of individual treatment goals one year after intrathecal baclofen (ITB) pump implantation in non-walking individuals with dyskinetic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: 71% of individuals fully achieved one or more treatment goals, and 97% partially achieved goals. Goal attainment was associated with higher baseline dystonia severity and pain improvement during treatment.
population_specificity: Non-walking individuals with severe dyskinetic cerebral palsy (GMFCS IV/V), aged 4-24 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current understanding of Disorders of Arousal (DOA), including their prevalence, genetic factors, clinical impacts, and underlying neural mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that DOA are prevalent in adults (2%-4%) and involve dissociated brain activity during episodes, with wake-like activation in motor and limbic regions but preserved sleep in frontoparietal networks. EEG and behavioral criteria now support DOA diagnosis, but treatment remains based on managing factors and clinician experience, lacking placebo-controlled trials.
population_specificity: Adults with Disorders of Arousal (DOA), including sleepwalking, sleep terrors, and confusional arousals.

study_goal: The researchers sought to synthesize qualitative literature on the care experiences of frontline nurses during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study identified three major themes in nurses' experiences: instability in an unpredictable context, uncertainty in care provision, and emotional demands of care. It highlighted the emotional impact on nurses and the need for better training, psycho-emotional support, and safe clinical environments.
population_specificity: Frontline nurses during the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: To analyze the effect of an automated mechanical peripheral stimulation (AMPS) session on functional performance and gait biomechanics in subjects with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: AMPS intervention increased activation of the gastrocnemius lateralis and tibialis anterior muscles during walking and improved functional performance (shorter TUG test time), but did not alter gait kinematics. Sham intervention reduced TA activation in certain gait phases.
population_specificity: 28 subjects with Parkinson's disease, aged 67±3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether perioperative duloxetine reduces opioid consumption and pain scores (including during walking) after thoracotomy.
results_summary: Duloxetine significantly reduced postoperative pain during walking (VAS-W) compared to placebo, with lower opioid requirements and no added side effects. Pain scores during walking were consistently lower in the duloxetine group at all measured intervals.
population_specificity: 60 patients scheduled for thoracotomy.
effective_dosage: 60 mg orally two hours before surgery and 24 hours after.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pairing transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) with obstacle negotiation practice enhances within-session improvements and retention of walking performance gains in older adults.
results_summary: All groups showed significant within-session gains in walking speed, but the sham-tDCS group outperformed the active-tDCS and no-tDCS groups. At one-week follow-up, the active-tDCS group exhibited better retention of gains compared to no-tDCS but not sham-tDCS.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 74.46 years) with self-reported walking difficulty.
effective_dosage: Ten practice trials of obstacle negotiation at fastest safe speed, paired with either active tDCS, sham tDCS, or no tDCS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of pharmacologic agents, specifically bosentan, in improving exercise capacity (measured via NYHA FC and 6-minute walking test) in patients with Fontan circulation.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that bosentan significantly improved NYHA FC and 6-minute walking test results in Fontan patients, indirectly enhancing exercise capacity. The effect was statistically significant (P=0.0008).
population_specificity: Patients with Fontan circulation (single functional ventricle).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fundamental movement skills-based dual-task training and dance training on gait performance in older women with dementia under single- and dual-task walking conditions.
results_summary: Both training programs significantly improved gait performance (speed, cadence, stride length) and reduced dual-task costs, with no significant differences between the two intervention groups.
population_specificity: Older women with dementia (aged 72-73 years).
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week, each lasting 50 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze changes in gait metrics during and after the 6-Minute Walk Test (6MWT) in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) across different disability levels.
results_summary: Most gait parameters (speed, cadence, step length, stability, regularity) deteriorated during the 6MWT, while others (step time, stance period, double support phase, variability, asymmetry) increased. These changes were more pronounced in PwMS with moderate-to-severe disability.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS; n=534) and healthy controls (n=166).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking test, not a dosage-based intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare frailty status and clinical characteristics, including walking speed, between patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) and those with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) in a super-aged Japanese population.
results_summary: HFpEF patients exhibited significantly slower comfortable 5 m walking speed compared to HFrEF patients, along with higher frailty prevalence and lower handgrip strength. Physical frailty was associated with extracardiac factors like advanced age and low albumin in HFpEF, and with female sex and anemia in HFrEF.
population_specificity: Elderly Japanese patients (median age 81 years) with heart failure, divided into HFpEF (61.2%) and HFrEF (38.8%) groups.

study_goal: To investigate whether long-term treatment with JPYF II granules is effective and safe for patients with stable, moderate to very severe COPD, focusing on quality of life and exercise capacity.
results_summary: JPYF II granules significantly improved quality of life (SGRQ score), reduced symptoms (CAT score), increased exercise capacity (6MWT), and decreased acute exacerbations compared to placebo. No significant differences were found in lung function, BODE index, or SpO₂.
population_specificity: Patients with stable, moderate to very severe COPD from six hospitals.

study_goal: To determine the benefits of aquatic physical therapy, including walking, as a rehabilitation strategy for knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: Aquatic physical therapy significantly improved pain, physical function, knee extension muscle strength, and walking ability (measured by TUGT) in knee osteoarthritis patients, but showed no significant improvements in joint symptoms, quality of life, flexibility, or body composition.
population_specificity: Knee osteoarthritis patients (883 participants across 13 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of interlaminar full-endoscopic discectomy versus conventional microscopic discectomy for treating lumbar disc herniation, including effects on walking distance/time and return to daily activities.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results regarding walking, as it is a planned trial with outcomes to be measured postoperatively at 12 months.
population_specificity: 100 participants with lumbar disc herniation (50 per surgical group).
study_duration: Outcomes assessed up to 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different methods of functional resistance training during walking affect muscle activation, gait biomechanics, and neural plasticity.
results_summary: The study found that various resistance methods (passive and robotic devices) produced device-specific changes in muscle activation, biomechanics, and aftereffects, with some evidence of task-specific neural excitability increases. The findings suggest that selecting appropriate resistive strategies can target patient-specific deficits.
population_specificity: Individuals with neuromusculoskeletal injuries resulting in weakness and gait impairments.
study_duration: Acute effects (after a single training session)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the Minimal Clinically Important Difference (MCID) for the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) and Comfortable Walking Speed (CWS) in older adults with acute cardiovascular disease (CVD) undergoing rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that the MCID for SPPB was 3 points and for CWS was 0.10 m/s, indicating clinically meaningful improvements in physical function for older adults with CVD. These findings help clinicians assess the effectiveness of cardiac rehabilitation interventions.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥75 years hospitalized for acute CVD and undergoing rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether trunk control, motion, and alignment return to normal after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and how this relates to functional mobility.
results_summary: The study found that pre-operative trunk motion and alignment abnormalities did not fully return to normal after TKA, with frontal plane recovery being faster than sagittal and transversal planes. Persistent sagittal imbalance (anteriorly shifted trunk position) was observed, suggesting the need for a biomechanical chain approach in rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the associations between the quantity, content, and specificity of action-plans and weight loss in a diabetes prevention study.
results_summary: Producing more action-plans was associated with greater weight loss, while specificity of action-plans did not show a significant association. Engagement in action-planning decreased over time.
population_specificity: 106 participants in a diabetes prevention study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an individualized and progressive multicomponent exercise program, including walking, on blood pressure, cardiorespiratory fitness, and body composition in long-term care residents.
results_summary: The intervention group, which included walking recommendations, maintained peak VO₂ levels, suggesting potential benefits for cardiorespiratory fitness, though specific walking-related outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Long-term care residents (112 participants across 10 facilities).

study_goal: To determine if robotic gait training is more effective than standard care for improving function in individuals with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant difference in six-minute walk test performance between robotic gait training and standard care interventions for individuals with cerebral palsy.
population_specificity: 188 individuals with cerebral palsy, ages 4-35, Gross Motor Function Classification System levels I-IV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different tDCS applications (anodal, bilateral, cathodal, and sham) on dual task gait performance and contralesional M1 activation in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Bilateral and cathodal tDCS improved dual task walking speed (CDT and MDT) compared to sham, and increased contralesional corticomotor inhibition (silent period) more than anodal and sham tDCS. One session of bilateral or cathodal tDCS enhanced dual task walking performance alongside increased corticomotor inhibition in chronic stroke.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (48 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Action Observation (AO) interventions in improving walking ability and motor control in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that AO interventions had positive effects on walking ability and motor symptoms like freezing of gait in PD patients, though efficacy varied due to heterogeneity in intervention features. Overall, AO improved functional abilities and motor control, with intervention dose and stimulus characteristics playing a key role.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients (227 participants across 7 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety, feasibility, tolerability, and acceptability of robotic exoskeleton-assisted mobilization in advanced heart failure patients.
results_summary: The study found that mobilization with the Myosuit was feasible and safe, with no adverse events reported. Patients showed no significant differences in perceived exertion or dyspnea with or without the device, and acceptability was high, with 85% interested in regular robot-assisted training.
population_specificity: Advanced heart failure patients (NYHA class III), mean age 49.4 years, 80% male.
effective_dosage: Single, standardized 60-minute rehabilitation exercise unit or activities of daily life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and usability of a mobile app-integrated home-based walking and resistance exercise program (GO-EXCAP) for older patients with myeloid neoplasms undergoing outpatient chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that GO-EXCAP was feasible and usable, with 82% of patients entering exercise data on the app at least half of the study days. Patients showed increased daily steps (from 2848 to 3184) and performed resistance exercises 26.2 minutes per day, 2.9 days per week.
population_specificity: Older patients (mean age 72 years) with myeloid neoplasms undergoing outpatient chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Progressive aerobic walking and resistance exercises (26.2 minutes per day, 2.9 days per week at low intensity).
study_duration: 2 cycles of treatment (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an aerobic training program (walking) on functional exercise tolerance, functional independence, and dyspnea in hospitalized patients with decompensated heart failure.
results_summary: The study found that the aerobic training program (ERIC-HF) was effective in increasing functional exercise tolerance and functional independence in patients with decompensated heart failure, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with decompensated heart failure (mean age 67 ± 11 years, 84% male).
study_duration: Follow-up at discharge (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding fascia iliaca compartment block (FICB) or local infiltration analgesia (LIA) to spinal anesthesia improves postoperative pain, opioid requirements, and mobility in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (THA).
results_summary: LIA reduced pain scores and opioid use compared to the control group, while FICB only lowered opioid requirements. All groups achieved similar mobility outcomes by 48 hours postoperatively.
population_specificity: 152 patients undergoing elective THA via direct anterior approach.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of subject-specific foot progression angle (SSFPA) gait modification on knee adduction moment and muscle activity in people with moderate knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: Walking with 10° toe-in showed the greatest reduction in knee adduction moment (17.52%), with immediate effects reducing it by 20.71%. After 30 minutes of gait retraining, lateral muscle co-contraction increased, suggesting enhanced unloading of the medial knee compartment.
population_specificity: Nineteen volunteers with moderate knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
effective_dosage: Four foot progression angle conditions (5° toe-out, 10° toe-out, 5° toe-in, 10° toe-in).
study_duration: Immediate effects and 30 minutes of gait retraining.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a Group Walking Program on reducing social physique anxiety and the risk of Eating Disorders in young-old women.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in social physique anxiety (P = 0.01) and Eating Disorders (P < 0.001) after an eight-week group walking intervention. The results suggest that group walking is an effective method for improving these outcomes in the studied population.
population_specificity: Young-old women (aged approximately 60-75) with medical records in Sari-Iran health centers, scoring ≥15 on SPAS and ≥20 on EAT-26.
effective_dosage: Not specified (group walking program, frequency not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of two different intensities of aerobic exercise (treadmill walking) or rest on autonomic, oculomotor, and vestibular function and symptom burden in recently concussed adolescent athletes compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: The study found that both concussed and healthy participants showed similar reductions in symptom severity and count, as well as improvements in some vestibular/ocular measures, with no adverse effects reported. The interventions were well-tolerated and provided brief therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Adolescent student-athletes aged 13-18, both recently concussed (within 3-7 days post-injury) and healthy controls.
effective_dosage: 20-minute treadmill walking sessions at 40% or 60% of age-predicted max heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intermittent walking (IW) versus continuous walking (CW) on time and distance to fatigability in persons with Multiple Sclerosis (pwMS).
results_summary: Participants walked significantly longer durations and distances before experiencing fatigue in the IW condition compared to the CW condition, suggesting intermittent walking improves walking endurance in pwMS.
population_specificity: 18 persons with Multiple Sclerosis (Expanded Disability Status Scale median of 4.75).
effective_dosage: Intermittent walking: 30 seconds treadmill walking alternated with 30 seconds seated rest; Continuous walking: treadmill walking without breaks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait biomechanics between the NU-FlexSIV Socket and the ischial containment (IC) socket in individuals with unilateral transfemoral amputation.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in gait variables between the two sockets at week 7, but when all time points were assessed, the NU-FlexSIV Socket showed greater prosthetic-side hip range of motion. No other significant effects were observed.
population_specificity: Individuals with unilateral transfemoral amputation (n=25 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (socket intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: 7 weeks per socket, with testing at 1, 4, and 7 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the presentation, diagnosis, and treatment of glomus tumors around the knee, including their association with walking-induced pain.
results_summary: The study found that glomus tumors around the knee can cause severe pain during walking or stair climbing, with surgical excision providing effective pain relief. Literature review indicated no significant differences in tumor location or illness duration between genders, and trauma history may be a contributing factor.
population_specificity: A 42-year-old female with a glomus tumor near the knee, plus a review of 36 published cases.
study_duration: 7 years of symptoms prior to intervention, with 18-month follow-up post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare standard fall prevention exercises with novel Fall Arrest Strategy Training in reducing injury risk during falls.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that both groups showed results, but specific outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Forty women with a mean age of 74.5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a general overview of the effects of commercial powered lower limb exoskeletons (EXOs) for medical purposes in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI), focusing on multiple domains including walking.
results_summary: The study found significant positive effects in the walking domain for several EXO devices (Ekso, ReWalk, HAL, and Indego), with no reports of negative effects due to EXO training. However, the heterogeneity of outcome measures and lack of high-quality studies limited general conclusions.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of Function-Focused Care for Acute Care (FFC-AC-EIT) in promoting physical activity, including walking, among hospitalized patients with dementia.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines an intervention to engage patients in physical activities like walking, but specific results on walking's effects are not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Hospitalized older patients with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the BOOST program (a physical and psychological group intervention) compared to best practice advice (BPA) for improving mobility and reducing disability in older adults with neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: The BOOST program showed significant improvements in walking capacity (6MWT) and reduced falls risk at 12 months, with modest improvements in disability scores (ODI) at 6 months but no significant difference at 12 months compared to BPA. No serious adverse events were reported for either intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults (average age 74.9 years, 57% female) with neurogenic claudication.
study_duration: 12 months (with data collected at 6 and 12 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe gross motor impairments, including walking, in pediatric patients with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) during and after chemotherapeutic treatment and identify assessment tools.
results_summary: The study found impairments in gross motor skills, including walking, during treatment intensification and maintenance, persisting up to 5-6 years post-treatment. Balance problems were noted early in treatment and were the most reported alteration in survivors.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) undergoing treatment and survivors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of contoured foot orthoses versus sham flat insoles in reducing walking pain associated with first MTP joint osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain reduction between contoured foot orthoses and sham insoles, with both groups showing similar outcomes. Secondary measures, including physical function and quality of life, also showed no superiority for foot orthoses.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥45 years with symptomatic radiographic first MTP joint osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Worn at all times when wearing shoes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a combined supervised and home-based task-oriented program in improving walking endurance, ability, and related outcomes in people with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study found that the task-oriented program significantly improved walking endurance (6MWT), walking ability (T25FW, TUG), fatigue (MFIS), and resting muscle oxygen consumption (rmVO₂) compared to usual care. Adherence was good, and the intervention was cardiorespiratory stressful, potentially reducing deconditioning.
population_specificity: People with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS) with EDSS scores 4-5.5 and unassisted walking ability.
effective_dosage: 10 supervised TOCT sessions over two weeks (Phase 1), followed by a 12-week home-based task-oriented program with monthly visits (Phase 2).
study_duration: 14 weeks total (2 weeks supervised + 12 weeks home-based).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of treadmill interventions in improving gait parameters in adults with neurological disorders, specifically stroke and Parkinson’s disease.
results_summary: Treadmill interventions significantly improved cadence and step length in stroke patients and step length and stride length in Parkinson’s disease patients. Overground physical therapy training had the largest effect on step width in PD patients.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥55 years with neurological disorders (stroke or Parkinson’s disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to distinguish between hemiplegic and normal walking using inertial signals from a freely located six-axis sensor in the pocket, without pre-processing, via a convolutional neural network.
results_summary: The optimized model achieved an accuracy of 0.78, precision of 0.80, recall of 0.80, and AUC-ROC of 0.80, demonstrating feasibility for hemiplegic gait classification using pocket-based sensors.
population_specificity: 42 subjects (21 hemiplegic patients, 21 controls; mean age 57.8 ± 13.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the differences in health effects of various forest-based activities, particularly walking, and their associated outcomes.
results_summary: Walking showed consistent positive health effects, with differences observed in anxiety and depression, cognitive function, stress hormone levels, and inflammation. However, most included studies had a high risk of bias and limited intervention specifics.
population_specificity: Participants aged 6-98 years (total n=6264, sample sizes ranging from 12-585).
effective_dosage: Activity time ranged between 10 and 240 minutes (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the usefulness of a mobile patient lift for early mobilisation in ICU patients on mechanical ventilation.
results_summary: The study will compare the time required to achieve standing (ICU mobility scale ≥4) between groups using a mobile lift (intervention) and those without (control), analyzed via Student's t-test. Results will be presented at conferences and published.
population_specificity: ICU patients aged ≥18, previously independent walkers, expected to require mechanical ventilation for ≥48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether specific exercise interventions were more effective than traditional prosthetic training in improving gait and balance in individuals with lower limb amputations.
results_summary: Exercise interventions significantly improved walking distance and speed compared to traditional training, but balance outcomes showed inconsistent results. The studies demonstrated overall good methodological quality.
population_specificity: Adults (>18 years old) with lower limb amputations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait patterns and functional outcomes between posterior cruciate retention (CR) and posterior cruciate substitution (PS) in total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between CR and PS groups in kinematic gait parameters, knee extension, walking speed, and Knee Society Score (KSS). However, the PS group showed a significantly larger knee flexion angle compared to the CR group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a home-based semi-supervised physiotherapy intervention, including walking exercises, to improve post-stroke mobility in a low-resource setting.
results_summary: The intervention was safe, with no adverse events reported, and led to improvements in functional exercise tolerance and upper extremity function, though handgrip strength and balance showed no significant changes. Participants were satisfied, but adherence was affected by external factors like weather and motivation.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients in a low-resource setting (Suriname), average age 61.8 years, 13 men.
effective_dosage: 3 days a week, including walking, functional, and mobilization exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a static nerve root foramen opening protocol, combined with walking and other interventions, could improve outcomes for patients with lumbar radiculopathy from disc herniation in an emergency hospital setting.
results_summary: The experimental group, which included the static lumbar foramen opening protocol alongside walking and medication, showed significantly better outcomes in pain, disability, and straight leg raise compared to the control group (walking and medication alone). The experimental group also consumed less medication, including opioids, with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: Patients with sciatica and moderate or large disc hernias, 75% of whom had neurological deficits, presenting at an emergency hospital department.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether action observation training, as an add-on to conventional physical rehabilitation, could improve gait performance in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in spatiotemporal gait parameters on the unaffected side and stride/step length on the affected side, while the sham group only improved in stance phase percentage.
population_specificity: Fourteen patients with chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: 12-minute observation training per session (exercises for experimental group, nature pictures for sham group) followed by 40-minute conventional physical training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of the Possover-LION procedure on mobility, sexual, urinary, and anorectal functions in patients with chronic spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that 72% of thoracic injury patients and 60% of cervical injury patients achieved walker-assisted gait at one year. Improvements were also noted in urinary incontinence, enuresis, fecal incontinence, and genital sensitivity.
population_specificity: 30 patients with chronic spinal cord injury (21 AIS A, eight AIS B, one AIS C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of early mobilization protocols, including walking, on ICU patients after cardiac surgery.
results_summary: The study found that early mobilization protocols, involving walking and other exercises, were implemented in the immediate postoperative period or first postoperative day, with sessions lasting 10 to 30 minutes twice daily. The protocols were generalist and low-intensity, using progressive mobilization techniques.
population_specificity: ICU patients recovering from cardiac surgery.
effective_dosage: Two daily physical therapy sessions, 10 to 30 minutes each.
study_duration: Immediate postoperative period or first postoperative day (specific duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers investigated the effect of liraglutide on pulmonary function in people with obesity and COPD, not specifically Walking.
results_summary: Liraglutide improved some measures of pulmonary function, including increased forced vital capacity and carbon monoxide diffusion capacity, and improved COPD assessment test scores, but no significant changes in forced expiratory volume in one second were observed.
population_specificity: 40 people with obesity and COPD from two outpatient clinics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of functional electrical stimulation (FES) bicycle therapy on motor function, gait pattern, spasticity, daily living activities, and aerobic capacity in children with cerebral palsy (CP) compared to sham stimulation and standard treatment.
results_summary: All groups showed significant improvements in motor function, gait pattern, spasticity, daily living activities, and aerobic capacity, but FES-cycling did not demonstrate superiority over sham stimulation or standard treatment. No significant differences were found among the groups in any clinical assessment parameter.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (GMFCS levels I-III) who received botulinum toxin type-A injections to lower extremities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether positive suggestions could enhance the effectiveness of a smartphone-based physical activity intervention by increasing participants' step counts and improving subjective outcomes like perceived app effectiveness and fatigue.
results_summary: The study found that positive suggestions increased participants' positive expectations and reduced fatigue but did not significantly affect their daily step counts. The intervention itself led to a significant increase in daily steps compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Participants in a web-based study (133 individuals, randomized into positive suggestions and control groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved app-based tasks and step tracking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the historical development and efficacy of supervised exercise training (SET) for improving walking ability in patients with claudication due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found strong evidence that SET, particularly intermittent treadmill walking, significantly improves walking ability in PAD patients with claudication. The evidence led to national coverage for SET by Medicare & Medicaid Services in 2017.
population_specificity: Patients with claudication due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Intermittent bouts of walking exercise to moderate claudication pain on a treadmill (specific frequency/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if treadmill training combined with routine physical therapy after botulinum toxin (BoNT-A) injection improves lower extremity muscle strength, selective motor control, and mobility in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that treadmill training significantly improved hip muscle strength, ankle selective motor control, walking speed, step lengths, and functional mobility compared to routine physical therapy alone. Both groups showed increased muscle strength, but the treadmill group had greater improvements in specific outcomes.
population_specificity: Children with spastic bilateral cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System levels II-III).
effective_dosage: Treadmill training (20 minutes, two sessions per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the cerebellum in mediating the aftereffects of Rhythmic Auditory Stimulation (RAS) on gait training in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that RAS-based gait training led to greater improvements in gait performance compared to non-RAS training, accompanied by a reshaping of cerebellum-brain functional connectivity, particularly in pre-motor, sensorimotor, and temporal cortices during specific gait-cycle phases. These findings suggest RAS may help restore internal timing mechanisms, improving gait in Parkinson's patients.
population_specificity: 50 patients with idiopathic Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a clinical score (ACLIS) to identify patients at high risk of ACL tears after knee ligament sprains, aiding emergency and primary-care physicians in specialist referral decisions.
results_summary: The ACLIS score, based on four key items (immediate knee instability, inability to resume activity, sensation of dislocation, and pivoting-contact injury), demonstrated high sensitivity (95%) and specificity (62%) for ACL tear diagnosis, with strong predictive values (PPV 88%, NPV 82%). Validation confirmed its reliability in emergency settings.
population_specificity: Patients with acute knee injuries (development cohort: 228 patients; validation cohort: 121 patients), predominantly male, mean age 28–32 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of dance training versus balance training on fall risk, physical and cognitive functions in older women, and to evaluate associations with circulating markers of neurodegeneration.
results_summary: Dance training improved walking speed, 6-minute walk test performance, and cognitive functions, while balance training also showed cognitive benefits. Improvements were linked to changes in amyloid precursor protein and serotonin concentrations.
population_specificity: 30 older women (aged 73.3 ± 4.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the 24-month efficacy and safety of a novel sirolimus-eluting stent (NiTiDES) for treating femoropopliteal disease, focusing on primary patency, functional outcomes, and clinical benefits.
results_summary: At 24 months, the stent showed high primary patency (83.4%) and freedom from target lesion revascularization (93.1%), with sustained functional and clinical improvements (82.1% of patients improved to Rutherford category 0 or 1). No major limb amputations were reported, and walking disability scores improved.
population_specificity: 100 patients with symptomatic femoropopliteal disease (Rutherford category 2-4, mean lesion length 5.8 ± 3.9 cm, 35.0% total occlusions).
effective_dosage: Not specified (drug-eluting stent with amphilimus formulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of testosterone and other androgenic-anabolic steroids in improving physical function, including walking speed, in older adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that testosterone supplementation showed dose-related improvements in lean body mass, strength, and other physical measures, but had less consistent effects on walking speed. Long-term efficacy and safety for improving physical function and reducing disability, falls, and fractures remain uncertain.
population_specificity: Older adults with sarcopenia (age-related or due to chronic disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility and efficacy of home-based neurofunctional training (HBNFT) versus home-based resistance training (HBRT) on ambulatory performance in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) and cognitive impairment.
results_summary: HBNFT significantly improved tandem walk test, SSST, and 6MWT compared to HBRT, with no adverse events reported. HBRT participants reported pain, muscle cramps, and extreme fatigue, while HBNFT was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Thirty males and females with MS (age 18-50, EDSS score ≤ 6, and cognitive impairment).
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week for eight weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether testosterone treatment in older men with low testosterone levels improves walking and other health outcomes.
results_summary: Testosterone treatment improved walking in older men with low testosterone levels, along with sexual function, mood, bone mineral density, and hemoglobin. However, it did not improve vitality or cognitive function, and potential risks like prostate cancer and heart disease remain unconfirmed.
population_specificity: Older men with unequivocally low serum testosterone concentrations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of veverimer in treating metabolic acidosis in women with CKD and its impact on physical function, including walking-related activities.
results_summary: Women treated with veverimer showed significant improvements in serum bicarbonate levels, physical function (including walking, stair climbing, and carrying groceries), and performance on the repeated chair stand test compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Women with chronic kidney disease (eGFR: 20-40 mL/min/1.73 m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular mechanisms underlying synaptic transmission and its role in motor functions like walking, as well as the impact of presynaptic molecule dysfunction in neurological disorders and aging.
results_summary: The study summarizes recent findings on presynaptic molecules in active zones, highlighting their role in neurotransmitter release and their dysfunction in motor and cognitive decline during aging and neurological disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of molecular mechanisms in general, not a specific human or animal population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of community-based rehabilitation (CBR) on physical functioning and activity of daily living (ADL) in patients with stroke (PWS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant improvement in physical functional capacity, particularly in mobility and the 6-metre walk test (6MWT), for PWS receiving CBR compared to controls. The study concluded that CBR is effective for improving physical functioning and ADL in PWS, though the evidence was limited to high-income countries.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke (PWS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to adapt and test the effectiveness of a pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) program, including walking, for people with post-TB lung disease (PTBLD) in Kyrgyzstan.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of walking or the PR program, as it describes the study design and aims rather than outcomes.
population_specificity: People with post-TB lung disease (PTBLD) in Kyrgyzstan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of S-flurbiprofen plaster (SFPP) compared to diclofenac gel in reducing pain and improving clinical symptoms in knee osteoarthritis patients, particularly focusing on pain during walking and rising from a chair.
results_summary: SFPP demonstrated non-inferiority to diclofenac gel in reducing knee pain when rising from a chair, with statistically significant improvements in clinical symptoms, pain on walking, and global assessments by both investigators and patients. The incidence of adverse events was low (5.8% for SFPP vs. 5.2% for diclofenac gel), mostly mild, and did not lead to discontinuation.
population_specificity: Knee osteoarthritis patients (n=311).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety and efficacy of tooth discolouration management, including the walking bleach technique for endodontically treated teeth.
results_summary: The study found that bleaching endodontically treated teeth can be safe and effective, though higher concentrations of hydrogen peroxide (30%-35%) are associated with external cervical root resorption. Multidisciplinary treatment considerations and patient expectations are important for aesthetic outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with tooth discolouration, particularly those with endodontically treated teeth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of biportal endoscopic discectomy versus microscopic discectomy for treating lumbar herniated discs, focusing on clinical outcomes like pain relief, disability improvement, and postoperative recovery.
results_summary: The study is designed to evaluate equivalence between biportal endoscopic and microscopic discectomy, with primary and secondary outcomes including pain scores, disability indices, quality of life, and surgical variables, but results are not yet reported as it is a prospective trial.
population_specificity: 100 participants (50 per group) with lumbar herniated discs.
study_duration: Assessments conducted at baseline, 2 weeks, and 3, 6, and 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the association between endometriosis-related chronic pain and its impact on daily life functions, including walking.
results_summary: Chronic pain from endometriosis was negatively associated with walking and other daily life activities, with 33.7% of women reporting moderate and 27.5% reporting severe limitations. Comorbid pain disorders exacerbated these limitations.
population_specificity: 510 women with endometriosis, 265 of whom experienced chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a 12-week walking-based lifestyle program on moderate-to-vigorous physical activity and sleep quality in adults aged 55+ years, and to determine if effects differed between good and poor sleepers.
results_summary: The program significantly increased moderate-to-vigorous physical activity but did not improve sleep, except for a slight increase in awakenings among good sleepers. No differences were found between good and poor sleepers regarding physical activity effects.
population_specificity: Adults aged 55+ years.
effective_dosage: 12-week progressive walking program, complemented by optional muscle strengthening and one educational session on healthy nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a remotely delivered weight loss intervention, including physical activity (walking), on diet and physical activity behaviors in female breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The intervention led to sustained improvements in adherence to cancer survivor recommendations and some improvements in diet and physical activity, supporting the health benefits of lifestyle programs for breast cancer survivors.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer survivors aged 18 to 75 years with a BMI of 25 to 45 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included 22 counseling calls and optional text messages over 12 months).
study_duration: 12 months (with follow-up assessments at 6, 12, and 18 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare short-term clinical and radiographic outcomes of toddler's fractures treated with long leg casting versus observation.
results_summary: Observation of toddler's fractures resulted in equivalent clinical and radiographic outcomes, higher family satisfaction, and fewer complications compared to long leg casting. Both groups showed significant improvement in functional scores over 8 weeks, with no displacement observed in any patient.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (median age 1.8-2.0 years) with nondisplaced metaphyseal fractures of the distal tibia (toddler's fractures).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if there are differences in lower limb muscle activation between young and older adults when responding to balance perturbations during walking.
results_summary: Older adults showed different adaptations in lower limb muscle activation compared to young adults during balance-perturbed walking, with increased co-contraction of ankle and knee joint muscles, especially during physical tasks. Coordination between agonist and antagonist muscles was found to be important for stabilization.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (age: 70 ± 4.5, females: 53.9%) and young adults (age: 23 ± 2.0, females: 49.1%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of ultrasound-guided genicular nerve block (GNB) and physical therapy (PT) in improving pain, functional capacity, and walking distance in patients with chronic knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Ultrasound-guided GNB showed greater pain reduction and increased walking distance compared to PT at 12 weeks, with both treatments improving pain and function. The GNB group retained better physical capacity improvements over time.
population_specificity: Patients aged 45-70 years with chronic knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (standard home exercise program alongside interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of the mild® Procedure combined with conventional medical management (CMM) versus CMM alone for patients with lumbar spinal stenosis suffering from neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: The study found that mild+CMM showed statistically significant improvements in patient-reported outcomes and walking tolerance compared to CMM alone, with no reported device- or procedure-related adverse events. The results demonstrated the superiority of mild+CMM as an early interventional therapy for symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis suffering from neurogenic claudication secondary to hypertrophic ligamentum flavum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a 12-week intensive circuit class therapy for improving gait, balance, fatigue, and depression symptoms in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in balance (FSBT), gait (TUG test), fatigue (MFIS), depression (BDI), walking ability (MSWS-12), and quality of life (SF-36 subscales) in the intervention group compared to the control group after 12 weeks of therapy.
population_specificity: 46 patients with relapsing-remitting MS (mean EDSS scores of 2.33 ± 0.74 in the intervention group and 2.04 ± 0.63 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Intensive circuit class therapy (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the TCM-modified Bushen Yiqi formula (MBYF) as an add-on to budesonide/formoterol in COPD patients, including its impact on walking ability measured by the 6-minute walking test (6MWT).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of MBYF on walking ability (6MWT), as the study is described as ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the recovery time of functional independence (including walking performance via the Timed Up & Go walking test) after radical cystectomy and compare outcomes between robot-assisted and open procedures.
results_summary: The study found that walking performance (TUGWT) recovered to baseline levels by 3 months post-surgery for both surgical approaches, with no significant difference between robot-assisted and open procedures. Hand grip strength and activities of daily living showed variable recovery times but no clinically meaningful differences between the two surgical methods.
population_specificity: 302 patients (84.1% men; mean age 68.0 years) who underwent radical cystectomy (150 robot-assisted, 152 open) across 15 US academic medical centers.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 2 years; functional measures assessed up to 6 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-month personalized home-based walking program could reduce intraplaque hemorrhage (IPH) and modulate inflammatory and biological markers in asymptomatic stroke patients with carotid stenosis.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that the walking intervention will reduce IPH and improve inflammatory and biological parameters, but results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic stroke patients (≥18 years old) with carotid stenosis ≥50% and no ischemic events for at least 6 months.
effective_dosage: Daily walking step goal individually tailored to each patient, monitored via a wristband.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardioprotective effects of halogenated anesthetic drugs (sevoflurane, desflurane, or isoflurane) compared to intravenous hypnotics (propofol) in cardiac-surgery patients, focusing on enzymatic routes and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Walking; it discusses ongoing research into anesthetic drugs' effects and awaits final results from the ACDHUVV-16 clinical trial.
population_specificity: Cardiac-surgery patients with heart failure associated with ischemia induced during extracorporeal circulation.

study_goal: The abstract does not focus on evaluating walking but rather discusses treatments for knee osteoarthritis, including PRP injections.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on walking; it mentions therapeutic physical exercise as part of general guidelines for knee OA management.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of neck surgery combined with structured rehabilitation or standard approach on dizziness and balance in patients with cervical radiculopathy.
results_summary: Patients improved significantly in dizziness and subjective balance shortly after surgery, and in standing balance at 6 months, with no differences between rehabilitation approaches. Baseline values, neck pain, and physical activity level influenced outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals (n=149) with cervical radiculopathy and dizziness and/or balance problems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of unsupervised physical activity (PA) interventions, including walking, for people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: Unsupervised PA interventions improved dyspnea and exercise capacity in people with COPD, were found to be safe, and had high adherence rates. Meta-analysis supported benefits in dyspnea (CRQ-D) and walking distance (6MWD, ISWD).
population_specificity: People with COPD (average age 68±10 years, 58.8% male, FEV not fully specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of interrupting prolonged sitting with frequent short bouts of standing and light-intensity walking on cardiometabolic health markers.
results_summary: Light-intensity walking significantly reduced postprandial glucose and insulin compared to prolonged sitting and was more effective than standing breaks. Neither standing nor walking affected systolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Mixed-sex adults aged >18 years, predominantly overweight or with obesity.
effective_dosage: Frequent short bouts (specific duration/frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of supervised exercise therapy (SET) versus primary endovascular revascularisation (ER) in improving walking distance and quality of life for patients with intermittent claudication caused by iliac artery obstruction.
results_summary: Both SET and ER significantly improved maximum walking distance and quality of life after one year, with no significant difference in walking distance between the two treatments. However, 29% of SET patients required ER within one year, and nearly half underwent additional interventions over 5.5 years.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication caused by iliac artery stenosis or occlusion.
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised exercise therapy and endovascular revascularisation protocols not detailed).
study_duration: 1 year primary follow-up, with mean follow-up of 5.5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the cerebral mechanism of opposing needling for managing acute pain after unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and its effects on brain activity and clinical pain outcomes.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized sham-controlled trial to assess opposing needling's impact on brain activity and pain relief post-TKA, using functional MRI and pain threshold measurements, but results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Patients with acute pain after unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the patient burden, including mobility and walking difficulties, associated with systemic amyloidosis.
results_summary: The study found that 28% of amyloidosis patients experienced difficulty in walking before diagnosis, highlighting its impact on mobility. Patients frequently reported problems with mobility and usual activities, but self-care was less affected.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with systemic amyloidosis (AL, ATTRv, ATTRwt, AA, and other rare forms), predominantly male (65%) with an average age of 66.8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pulmonary artery denervation (PADN) on pulmonary hypertension (pH) patients, focusing on outcomes like 6-minute walking distance, cardiac output, and mortality.
results_summary: PADN improved 6-minute walking distance, reduced mean pulmonary artery pressure and pulmonary vascular resistance, and increased cardiac output, but had no significant effect on left ventricular end-systolic diameter, readmission rate, mortality, or cardiac function.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary hypertension (339 participants across five controlled experiments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how individualised physiotherapy or advice influenced disability items, including Walking, in people with low back pain.
results_summary: The study found strong associations between Walking and Standing at week 10, suggesting improvements in mobility-related disability. Walking was not directly impacted by treatment but was linked to other disability items.
population_specificity: Adults with low back pain (n = 300).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) plus physiotherapy versus physiotherapy alone on walking ability in patients with subacute stroke and hemiplegia.
results_summary: The RAGT device group showed greater improvements in walking ability (FIM-walk score) and Barthel ADL index compared to the control group receiving only ground ambulation training. The study concluded that RAGT combined with physiotherapy led to early improvements in walking function.
population_specificity: Patients with subacute stroke and hemiplegia (N=26).
effective_dosage: 30 training sessions (5 days/week for 6 weeks), including 60 minutes of conventional physiotherapy and 60 minutes of ambulation training (RAGT group: 40 minutes robotic training + 20 minutes ground ambulation; control group: 60 minutes ground ambulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of physical activity, including walking, as an adjunct treatment to compression on wound healing and recurrence in patients with venous leg ulcers.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity interventions, including walking, showed potential benefits in improving wound healing outcomes, with resistance exercises combined with ankle/foot range of motion exercises minimizing ulcer size by day 12. However, only one study specifically reported aerobic/walking exercises among the interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with venous leg ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a walking-focused, proactive coaching intervention could improve chronic pain outcomes among Black patients compared to usual care.
results_summary: The intervention did not produce statistically significant improvements in the primary outcome (pain-related physical functioning) but showed modest improvements in pain intensity, interference, and global impression of change at 3 and 6 months.
population_specificity: Black patients at the Atlanta VA Health Care System with moderate to severe chronic back, hip, or knee pain.
effective_dosage: Six telephone coaching sessions over 8-14 weeks.

study_goal: To investigate the efficacy of home-based gait training using the wearable Stride Management Assist (SMA) exoskeleton in people with moderately advanced Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The SMA group showed a significant increase in distance traversed during the 3-minute walk test (141.4 m to 154.7 m, p=0.023) and a decrease in physiological cost index (0.29 to 0.13, p=0.046), while the control group showed no marked changes. The between-group difference in the 3-minute walk test was not statistically significant (p=0.109).
population_specificity: Outpatients with idiopathic Parkinson's disease (Hoehn and Yahr stage 2-4 in the ON state) capable of walking independently with or without walk aids.
effective_dosage: Gait training for approximately 30 minutes, 10 times over 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an optimized epidural electrical stimulation (EES) approach targeting dorsal roots could restore diverse motor activities, including walking, in individuals with severe spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that activity-specific stimulation programs enabled three individuals with complete sensorimotor paralysis to stand, walk, cycle, swim, and control trunk movements within a single day, with neurorehabilitation further improving these abilities for community use.
population_specificity: Three individuals with complete sensorimotor paralysis due to spinal cord injury.
study_duration: Intervention effects were observed within a single day, with neurorehabilitation extending benefits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the fall preventive effects of treadmill-based perturbation balance training (PBT) versus regular treadmill walking among older adults.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to evaluate fall rates and secondary fall-related risk factors, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 65 years or more.
effective_dosage: Treadmill-PBT group receives 40 slip/trip perturbations per session; treadmill walking group dosage not specified.
study_duration: Four sessions (three initial within a week, one booster at 26 weeks), with follow-up for 52 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of long-term Tai Chi and brisk walking on motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease patients and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Brisk walking showed improvements in motor symptoms but was less effective than Tai Chi in improving balance (BBS) and step width. The study did not highlight significant adverse effects for walking.
population_specificity: Early-stage Parkinson's disease patients (n=31 in brisk walking group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency/duration implied by intervention length).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between myelin water imaging (MWI) and functional domains relevant to multiple sclerosis (MS), including walking and cognitive function.
results_summary: Decreased myelin water fraction (MWF) was associated with higher disability and worse motor and cognitive performance in MS patients, but only five studies specifically examined structure-function relationships related to walking.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare characteristics between middle-aged and older prosthesis users with and without cognitive impairment and determine whether cognitive impairment affects perceived physical function.
results_summary: The study found that cognitive impairment was common (23.5% of participants) and associated with worse perceived physical function, even after adjusting for depressive symptoms, prosthesis satisfaction, chronic conditions, and assistive device use. Participants with cognitive impairment were older, had more chronic conditions, more depressive symptoms, and were more likely to use assistive devices.
population_specificity: Adults 45 years or older, at least 1-year post lower limb amputation, who were walking independently with a prosthesis (N=119).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and implementation challenges of supervised exercise therapy (SET), primarily involving structured walking, for improving symptoms, function, and clinical outcomes in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that SET, based on structured walking protocols, is a first-line therapy supported by Class IA guidelines for symptomatic PAD, effectively improving symptoms and clinical outcomes. However, challenges in awareness, access, and implementation persist, prompting exploration of digital and hybrid approaches to enhance accessibility.
population_specificity: Older adults with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of preoperative rehabilitation (including physiotherapy exercises) on subjective and objective outcomes after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) compared to a control group.
results_summary: Preoperative physiotherapy interventions showed short-term improvements in pain, hospital stay, and functional performance post-TKA, but no prolonged effects on knee motion or function between 3-12 months. Long-term outcomes were comparable between intervention and control groups.
population_specificity: Patients with severe osteoarthritis undergoing total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and radiological outcomes of third-generation minimally invasive chevron and Akin osteotomies (MICA) for treating severe hallux valgus deformity.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in patient-reported outcomes (MOXFQ scores) and radiographic deformity correction (HVA and IMA) two years post-surgery, with a complication rate of 18.8% and a screw removal rate of 5.6%.
population_specificity: 78 patients (73 female, 5 male) with severe hallux valgus deformity (HVA ≥40° and/or IMA ≥20°).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) or OMT combined with osteopathic cranial manipulative medicine (OCMM) could improve gait kinematics in individuals with Parkinson's disease by addressing joint restrictions and increasing range of motion in the lower limb.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with Parkinson's disease had significantly reduced hip and knee extension during walking compared to controls. A single session of OMT combined with OCMM (OMT-WB) resulted in a significant increase in total sagittal hip range of motion, but no significant differences were observed in joint angle waveforms during the gait cycle.
population_specificity: Individuals with idiopathic Parkinson's disease (Hoehn and Yahr stages 1.0-3.0) and age-matched healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Single session of OMT-WB, OMT-ND, or sham treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical progression and genetic characteristics of OPMD patients in the Canary Islands with a European cohort.
results_summary: The study found that OPMD progression was milder in the Canary cohort, with lower rates of limb weakness, need for walking assistance, and severe dysphagia compared to European patients. Nearly 95% of Canary patients carried the (GCN)15 expanded allele, suggesting a potential founder effect.
population_specificity: 123 OPMD patients from the Canary Islands and 139 OPMD patients from Europe.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic exercise, including walking, reduces pain sensitization in individuals with chronic musculoskeletal pain.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic exercise (walking or cycling) increased pressure pain thresholds or decreased pain ratings, with a median improvement of 10.6% in pain sensitization. Improvements were observed after one session in observational studies and after 2-12 weeks in clinical trials.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic musculoskeletal pain (excluding specific subgroups like fibromyalgia).
effective_dosage: Submaximal intensity with incremental increases, duration of 4-60 minutes.
study_duration: Ranged from one session to 2-12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of respiratory rehabilitation (including walking as part of exercise capacity) in patients recovering from SARS.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in exercise capacity (6-MWD) and pulmonary function test parameters but no significant improvement in activities of daily living or quality of life. No significant adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from SARS infection.
effective_dosage: Not specified (respiratory rehabilitation for at least six days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional and biomechanical outcomes in patients after primary ACL repair with augmentation, ACL reconstruction, and healthy controls, including walking performance.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking effects, as the study is experimental and data collection is prospective.
population_specificity: Patients 2 years after ACL repair with InternalBrace augmentation, patients 2 years after ACL reconstruction using hamstring autografts, and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how mobility changes over 6 months in people unable to walk at 8-weeks post-Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) and whether postural alignment is associated with mobility improvements.
results_summary: Participants showed significant improvements in mobility scores (COVS, secondary measures, and FIM) over time. Improved postural alignment in sitting and standing was associated with better mobility, though walking alignment changes were less clear.
population_specificity: Fourteen adults with ABI and a reference sample of 30 healthy adults.

study_goal: To determine if treadmill training combined with self-management education during stroke rehabilitation increases physical activity more than usual gait training.
results_summary: After 8 weeks, the experimental group took 1436 more steps/day than the control group, with this effect largely maintained at 6 months (871 more steps/day). No differences were found in other outcomes like walking ability or cardiorespiratory fitness.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors undergoing rehabilitation who could walk independently.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes, three times a week for 8 weeks (treadmill training at 40-60% heart rate reserve).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how long cognitive performance benefits are sustained after breaking up sedentary behavior (e.g., walking) in office-based environments.
results_summary: The study found mixed impacts of breaking up sitting interventions (including walking) on cognitive performance, with some studies showing significant benefits in working memory, attention, and psychomotor function for up to 30 minutes post-intervention. No studies evaluated benefits beyond 30 minutes or their applicability to tasks outside work.
population_specificity: Office-based workers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if belt electrode skeletal muscle electrical stimulation (B-SES) combined with conventional physical therapy improves postoperative lower limb function and walking ability in diabetic patients who underwent minor amputations.
results_summary: The study compared B-SES plus conventional therapy to conventional therapy alone, measuring ankle range of motion, knee extension strength, ambulation status, and quality of life. Results were evaluated at baseline, 2 weeks, and 4 weeks post-intervention, but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients who had undergone minor amputations.
effective_dosage: B-SES for 20 minutes daily alongside 20 minutes of conventional physical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of water-based treadmill walking training versus land-based treadmill walking training for improving muscle strength, proprioception, and knee performance in patients recovering from ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: Both water-based and land-based treadmill training significantly improved muscle strength, proprioception, and knee performance after 3 weeks. Water-based training showed greater improvements in knee extensor strength, proprioception, and knee performance compared to land-based training, though no differences were observed in knee flexor strength or balance indices.
population_specificity: Sixty patients undergoing rehabilitation following ACL reconstruction.

study_goal: To determine if a 12-week exoskeleton-based robotic gait training regimen improves independent gait speed in community-dwelling individuals with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvement in raw gait speed, but a greater proportion of participants in the exoskeleton group showed improved clinical ambulation status. Secondary outcome measures did not show significant improvements.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling individuals with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury (AIS-C and D, >1 year post-injury) and residual stepping ability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acoustic insole feedback training improves retention of prescribed partial weight bearing (PWB) adherence compared to conventional static training using a bathroom scale.
results_summary: The insole feedback group showed significantly improved immediate and long-term PWB adherence during walking, with an 86% reduction in overload rate and significant reductions in mean and maximum load compared to the conventional training group.
population_specificity: 24 volunteers randomized into two groups.
effective_dosage: Initial PWB training (20 kg) of one randomized leg.
study_duration: Immediate and one-week retention effects were analyzed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Liuzijue Qigong (a form of exercise, not walking) in improving lung function, exercise capacity, and quality of life in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found that Liuzijue Qigong significantly improved lung function, exercise capacity, health status, mental status, and quality of life in COPD patients, with statistically significant improvements across multiple outcome measures.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of walking meditation on ankle proprioception and balance in individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI) and compare it with rubber-band exercise.
results_summary: Walking meditation significantly improved ankle proprioception at specific plantarflexion angles and enhanced balance performance, while rubber-band exercise also improved balance but not proprioception. Both interventions outperformed the control group in balance improvements.
population_specificity: 32 participants with chronic ankle instability (CAI), aged 20.3 ± 1.8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of early physiotherapy, including walking, in severe COVID-19 patients with prolonged ICU stays.
results_summary: The study found that early physiotherapy was feasible and safe, with few minor adverse events. Patients took an average of 27 days from intubation to walking, and over half were discharged home, while others required rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Severe COVID-19 patients admitted to the ICU, requiring invasive mechanical ventilation for >24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gait and muscle function normalize beyond one year postoperatively in patients who underwent Total Hip Arthroplasty (THA) via the Minimally Invasive Anterior Approach (MIAA).
results_summary: The study found persistent walking deficits, reduced muscle strength in the gluteus medius and maximus, and altered kinetic and kinematic parameters more than one year postoperatively, indicating compensatory mechanisms.
population_specificity: 15 patients (64.6±6.6 years) post-THA via MIAA and 12 asymptomatic controls (68.9±9.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term functional outcomes, hip function, and complications in patients under 70 years old who underwent internal fixation for femoral neck fractures.
results_summary: Ten years post-surgery, most patients had normal functional test results, muscle strength, and good hip function, but a significant portion exhibited osteopenia, osteoporosis, or sarcopenia, highlighting the need for resistance training.
population_specificity: Patients aged 20-69 years with femoral neck fractures treated with internal fixation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of high-intensity non-invasive ventilation (HINIV) on diaphragm muscle function and respiratory performance in patients with hypercapnic chronic respiratory failure (HCRF) due to severe COPD.
results_summary: After 12 months of HINIV, patients showed significant improvements in respiratory function (FVC, FEV1, MIP), 6-minute-walking test (6MWT), and diaphragmatic thickening fraction, along with reduced hypercapnia and improved quality of life in respiratory symptoms, physical function, and sleep.
population_specificity: Patients with very severe chronic obstruction to airflow and hypercapnic chronic respiratory failure (HCRF), mean age 60.8 years, 63% male.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define usual physiotherapy care for ambulant children with cerebral palsy (CP) to support clinical guidelines and measure fidelity in control groups of trials.
results_summary: Physiotherapists reached high consensus on five outcome measures and nine areas of assessment, with moderate consensus on task-specific training delivered weekly for 4-6 weeks.
