They also agreed on modified sport/fitness activities and long-term monitoring for certain CP severity levels.
population_specificity: Ambulant children with cerebral palsy (CP) in the United Kingdom.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and synthesize patellofemoral joint reaction force (PFJRF) during everyday activities, therapeutic exercises, and physical interventions in healthy individuals and those with patellofemoral pain or osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that walking exerts a relatively low PFJRF (0.9±0.4 BW in healthy individuals, 0.8±0.2 BW in those with patellofemoral pain, and 1.3±0.5 BW in those with OA). No discernable differences in peak PFJRF during walking were observed between healthy individuals and those with patellofemoral pain/OA.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals, those with patellofemoral pain, and those with patellofemoral osteoarthritis/articular cartilage defects.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study reviewed biomechanical forces, not dosage).
study_duration: Not applicable (systematic review, not an intervention study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term prevalence and risk factors for post-acute COVID-19 sequelae (PASC), including limitations in walking and other physical activities, approximately 1 year after infection.
results_summary: The study found that 22.1% of respondents reported limitations in walking one block, indicating significant deterioration in effort tolerance. Persistent symptoms and functional limitations were common, affecting daily exercise tolerance, and were not limited to specific patient groups.
population_specificity: Survivors of acute COVID-19 infection requiring Emergency Department presentation or hospitalization, with a mean age of 59.2 years, 44.5% female, and 70.8% non-White.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 332 days (IQR 325-344) after hospital presentation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of self-management interventions, including walking, in improving mobility outcomes for stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that self-management interventions, integrated with rehabilitation therapy, improved functional mobility, walking ability, self-efficacy, physical activity participation, and quality of life for stroke survivors. Participants perceived these interventions as valuable for their rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature to understand the mechanical function of the iliotibial band (ITB) during movements like walking and running, and how anatomical variation, posture, and muscle activation influence it.
results_summary: The study found that the mechanical function of the ITB is poorly understood, particularly its role in walking and running, and highlighted the lack of robust evidence for effective treatments for iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS).
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify quantitative motor biomarkers in degenerative ataxias during real-life turning movements, sensitive to changes both longitudinally and at the preataxic stage.
results_summary: Lateral velocity change (LVC) during turning effectively differentiated ataxic and preataxic subjects from healthy controls, correlated with clinical ataxia severity, and detected longitudinal changes better than general turning measures or clinical scores.
population_specificity: Degenerative cerebellar disease patients (including preataxic mutation carriers) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the ABCDEF pulmonary rehabilitation program, which includes walking (via "dance in the square"), on lung function, exercise tolerance, and postoperative outcomes in lung cancer patients after thoracoscopic pneumonectomy.
results_summary: The ABCDEF program improved mid-term lung function and exercise tolerance at 3 months post-discharge, reduced postoperative complications, and shortened hospital stays, though no immediate effects were seen on discharge day.
population_specificity: 90 patients who underwent thoracoscopic pneumonectomy, divided into experimental and control groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included Acapella training, breathing exercises, cycling, dance, education, and follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for the effect of interventions targeting plantar intrinsic foot muscle (PIFM) strengthening on dynamic balance control and foot function during gait in adults.
results_summary: Low-certainty evidence suggests PIFM strengthening exercises improve vertical ground reaction force during gait, and very low-certainty evidence indicates benefits for dynamic balance control. No evidence was found for effects on medial longitudinal foot arch kinematics.
population_specificity: Primarily younger populations, with a noted need for studies in older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of corticosteroids (intravenous methylprednisolone and oral prednisolone) in improving walking disabilities in patients with HTLV-1-associated myelopathy (HAM), comparing rapid and slow progressors.
results_summary: In rapid progressors, all four patients receiving intravenous methylprednisolone plus oral prednisolone achieved the primary outcome (≥1-grade improvement in motor disability or ≥30% improvement in 10 m walking time), compared to only one of four without intravenous methylprednisolone. For slow progressors, the study assessed changes in 10 m walking time at week 24, but results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with HTLV-1-associated myelopathy (HAM), categorized as rapid (n=8) or slow (n=30) progressors based on walking disability progression.
effective_dosage: Rapid progressors: 3-day course of intravenous methylprednisolone plus oral prednisolone; slow progressors: oral prednisolone or placebo (dosage not specified).
study_duration: Rapid progressors: 2 weeks (primary outcome); slow progressors: 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of SUBAR-assisted gait training on gait parameters in patients with chronic stroke compared to conventional physiotherapy.
results_summary: SUBAR-assisted gait training improved some gait parameters (e.g., MAS and step length) but showed no significant difference in most outcomes compared to conventional physiotherapy. The control group showed significant improvements in BBS, MAS, and stride length.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic stroke (≥6 months post-onset) and functional ambulation category scores ≥3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of non-operative treatments, including manual therapy and exercise, for lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) with neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: The study found moderate-quality evidence that manual therapy and exercise provide clinically significant short-term improvements in symptoms and function compared to medical care or community-based exercise. Epidural steroids were found ineffective, while other non-operative interventions lacked sufficient evidence for conclusions.
population_specificity: Older adults diagnosed with neurogenic claudication due to imaging-confirmed lumbar spinal stenosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop prediction models for resuming domestic chores among mild stroke patients, focusing on factors like walking speed.
results_summary: Walking speed was a significant predictor for resuming various domestic chores, including preparing meals, washing up, washing clothes, light and heavy housework, and local shopping. Cognitive function and self-efficacy also contributed to some models.
population_specificity: Mild stroke patients discharged from specialized rehabilitation wards.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the functional and radiological outcomes of COVID-19 patients, including their performance in the 6-minute walking test (6MWT), at 2 and 6 months post-hospitalization.
results_summary: The study found that 6MWT performance improved between 2 and 6 months post-COVID-19 (p < 0.001). Patients with more severe acute pneumonia (PaO2/FiO2 <200) performed worse on the 6MWT at both time points and had more extended radiological abnormalities at 6 months.
population_specificity: Patients hospitalized for COVID-19

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of deventilation syndrome on COPD patients, including its impact on exercise tolerance measured by the 6-minute walking test (6MWT).
results_summary: Patients with deventilation syndrome showed reduced exercise tolerance (measured by 6MWT) and increased dyspnea after NIV mask removal, which improved with non-invasive pursed lip breathing ventilation (PLBV).
population_specificity: COPD patients with chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of mHealth interventions in promoting physical activity (including walking) and weight loss among workers.
results_summary: The study found that mHealth interventions significantly improved physical activity (SMD 0.22, 95% CI 0.03-0.41; P<.001), though over half of the included studies had a high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Workers (general workforce, no specific industry or demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the genetic cause of hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP) in a 7-year-old girl presenting with progressive walking difficulty and spastic paraparesis.
results_summary: The study identified a novel homozygous missense variation in the RNF170 gene, confirming the diagnosis of HSP, and discussed previously reported cases of RNF170-linked HSP.
population_specificity: A 7-year-old girl from a consanguineous Iraqi family with progressive walking difficulty and lower limb spastic paraparesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of modified pilates exercises (MPE) and neurodevelopmental therapy (NDT) on trunk control, postural control, gait, and balance in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: The study found that MPE significantly improved trunk control, postural control, gait, and balance compared to NDT, with multiple tests showing statistically significant differences favoring the MPE group.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (GMFCS levels I-III), aged 9-10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a caregiver-mediated exercise program using a blended care approach could improve mobility and independence in activities of daily living (ADL) for patients in the first 6 months poststroke.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that the Armed4Stroke program would enhance self-reported mobility and ADL independence, potentially enabling early discharge. It also suggested that caregiver involvement and blended care support could improve care transition as professional support decreases.
population_specificity: Patient-caregiver dyads within the first 3 months poststroke.
effective_dosage: Minimum of 5 sessions per week, 30 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation and scalability of a health coaching and text messaging intervention (ComeBACK) to improve walking as a physical activity intervention.
results_summary: The study describes a protocol for a process evaluation using the PRACTIS guide to assess barriers and facilitators for implementation and scale-up, but no results on walking outcomes are provided.
population_specificity: Trial participants, health coaches, and health service stakeholders (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of reward in neurorehabilitation, particularly its impact on motor skill consolidation and retention in tasks like walking and activities of daily living.
results_summary: The study suggests that reward, but not punishment, enhances motor skill consolidation and retention in healthy humans, though its role in neurorehabilitation for complex tasks like walking remains incompletely understood.
population_specificity: Patients with brain lesions and healthy humans (for comparative insights).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of aerobic exercise (brisk walking) on sweet taste perception and glycemic control in people with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The aerobic exercise group showed significantly increased sensitivity to higher sucrose concentrations and reduced sweet taste preference, along with improved glycemic control (reduced HbA1c levels) compared to controls.
population_specificity: 225 people with type 2 diabetes aged 35-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of game-based circuit exercise versus conventional circuit exercise on functional outcomes, motivation, self-efficacy, and quality of life in stroke survivors, and to assess the sustainability of these outcomes at 12 and 24 weeks post-trial.
results_summary: The study compared game-based and conventional circuit exercises, measuring outcomes like lower limb strength, postural stability, aerobic endurance, motivation, self-efficacy, and quality of life. Results were not detailed in the abstract, but the study design suggests a rigorous evaluation of these outcomes.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a smartphone-delivered multicomponent lifestyle medicine intervention, including walking, for managing depressive symptoms in adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking activity (d = 0.55) and total activity levels in the intervention group compared to the control group, though no significant differences were observed in vigorous or moderate exercise levels.
population_specificity: Adult Chinese population with at least moderate depressive symptoms (Patient Health Questionnaire-9 score ≥10).
study_duration: 8 weekly sessions, with assessments at Week 9 and Week 13.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES) improves activity and participation in daily life for children with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy and to assess its effects on body functions and activities.
results_summary: The study is designed as a randomized crossover trial to compare FES with conventional AFO treatment, focusing on improvements in daily activities, ankle kinematics, and cost-effectiveness, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-18 years with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy (GMFCS level I or II) and unilateral foot drop.
effective_dosage: Not specified (FES treatment involves using the WalkAide® device during gait).
study_duration: 12 weeks per treatment (FES and AFO), separated by a 6-week washout phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a simple resistance intervention (SRI) program, which included walking, on preventing sarcopenia and improving physiological outcomes in older Thai adults.
results_summary: The SRI program significantly improved hand grip, skeletal muscle mass index, and walking speed in the intervention group compared to the control group after 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older Thai adults (aged not specified) in Chiang Mai, Thailand.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of resistance exercise (including walking) three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the construction, blinding methods, and biomechanical validation of sham insoles used in placebo-controlled trials for walking-related interventions.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent construction, blinding, and biomechanical validation of sham insoles, casting doubt on the reliability of evidence supporting insole prescriptions. Only 19% of sham insoles were described sufficiently for replication, and 58% of studies were double-blinded, though many lacked detailed blinding methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on methodology of level I-II therapeutic evidence studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of seasonality on physical activity, including walking, across different countries and populations.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity levels, including walking, vary by season, with higher activity in summer and lower activity in winter. Sedentary behavior showed the opposite trend.
population_specificity: Adults from 18 different countries, including those with various pathologies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and safety of regular structured exercise training, including walking, on patient-important outcomes such as death, cardiovascular events, fatigue, functional capacity, pain, and depression in adults undergoing dialysis.
results_summary: Exercise training, including walking, may improve fatigue, the physical component of quality of life, and functional capacity, and probably improves depressive symptoms, particularly when maintained beyond four months. However, its effects on death, cardiovascular events, and the mental component of quality of life remain uncertain due to low certainty evidence.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing maintenance dialysis (including peritoneal dialysis).
effective_dosage: Most interventions took place thrice weekly during dialysis treatments, with durations ranging from eight weeks to two years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a home-based physical training and activity promotion program, including walking, on physical capacity, physical activity, and psychosocial status in older adults with cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in physical capacity (SPPB) compared to the control group, with benefits persisting during follow-up. However, no differences were observed in physical activity levels, though secondary outcomes like fear of falling and activity avoidance improved.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 82.3 ± 6.0 years) with mild to moderate cognitive impairment (MMSE: 23.3 ± 2.4) and high levels of multimorbidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the independent and joint effects of adaptive goal setting and immediate financial reinforcement on increasing daily walking among insufficiently active adults.
results_summary: Adaptive goal setting and immediate financial reinforcement significantly increased moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, with the combined intervention group showing the greatest improvement (16.52 minutes/day). Immediate reinforcement alone also outperformed delayed reinforcement (16.54 vs. 9.91 minutes/day).
population_specificity: 512 adults (64.5% female, aged 18-60 years, 18.8% Hispanic, 6.1% African American, 83% White) who were insufficiently active.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a virtual soccer game on balance, gait function, and kick speed in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injuries.
results_summary: The experimental group showed superior performance in chair stand tests, timed up-and-go tests, 10-meter walking tests, and kick speed compared to the control group, with all improvements statistically significant (P < 0.05). The study concluded that VR rehabilitation improves dynamic and static balance while reducing fall risk in this population.
population_specificity: Forty participants with incomplete spinal cord injuries (Asia impairment scale grades C-D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess long-term outcomes, including walking capacity, in survivors of critical illness from COVID-19.
results_summary: The 6-min walk test improved gradually over time and was almost back to normal by 12 months, indicating recovery in walking capacity.
population_specificity: Survivors of critical illness from COVID-19 (92 participants, 78% requiring mechanical ventilation) from four hospitals in Hubei Province, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use and user experience of a COVID-19 app among healthcare workers in a hospital setting.
results_summary: The COVID-19 app was widely used by healthcare workers, with high satisfaction rates for clarity, ease of use, speed, and usefulness. It was primarily used for quick information lookup, especially when walking between locations.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers (medical specialists, residents, nurses, management, and others) in a 900-bed tertiary care hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 20-m and 30-m walkway lengths on the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that a 30-m walkway resulted in a significantly longer walking distance (359.85 m vs. 337.82 m) and fewer turns compared to a 20-m walkway. Patients using the 20-m walkway also exhibited higher systolic blood pressure post-test, though other physiological parameters and dyspnea scores did not differ.
population_specificity: COPD patients (92% male, mean age 69.1 years, 50% with cardiovascular disease).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking test, not a supplement).
study_duration: Single session per walkway length (crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-resource behavioral intervention (Walking Away from Diabetes) could promote sustained physical activity in prediabetic adults, with and without mobile health support, compared to a control group.
results_summary: The intervention, combined with text messaging and telephone support, led to modest increases in physical activity (500+ steps/day) at 12 months, but these effects were not sustained at 48 months. Neither intervention proved cost-effective.
population_specificity: Adults with prediabetes (median age 61, median BMI 28.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included a 3-hour group session, annual refreshers, and optional mobile health support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of nusinersen treatment on quality of life (QoL) and motor function in adult patients with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in QoL domains (weakness, fatigue, activities, independence, social relationships, emotions, body image) and motor function (HFMSE, RULM) over 14 months of nusinersen treatment, except for muscle locking and pain. SMA3 non-walkers showed better activity improvements compared to walkers.
population_specificity: Adult patients (≥18 years) with SMA types 2, 3, and 4.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of Transcutaneous Electric Nerve Stimulation (TENS) on pain, function, walking ability, and stiffness in people with Knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: TENS significantly relieved pain, decreased dysfunction, and improved walking ability in people with KOA, but it was not effective for stiffness. Combining TENS with other interventions produced superior outcomes compared to other interventions alone.
population_specificity: People with Knee osteoarthritis (KOA), age range 54-85, 74% female.
study_duration: Short term (immediately after intervention), medium term (<four weeks), and long term (≥ four weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of walking steps on the quality of bowel preparation before colonoscopy in outpatients.
results_summary: The study found a curving relationship between walking steps and bowel preparation quality, with more steps associated with better preparation. Overweight, not drinking, walking steps, and timing of PEG intake were independent factors affecting preparation quality.
population_specificity: 150 outpatients undergoing colonoscopy in 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining ankle fusion with tibial lengthening using a magnetic internal lengthening nail to address limb length discrepancy and ankle deformity.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in limb length discrepancy (final mean LLD of 1 cm vs. preoperative 4.9 cm), with all patients achieving plantigrade feet and reporting minimal to no pain. All patients reported improved functional walking post-surgery.
population_specificity: 17 patients (18 limbs) with preoperative limb length discrepancy and ankle deformity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize scientific literature on prehospital blood use, emphasizing en route care, calcium administration, and the importance of trained providers and logistical support.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the shift toward using FDA-approved cold-stored whole blood and the operational need for walking blood banks and point-of-injury transfusion, stressing the importance of focused training and supervision.
population_specificity: Prehospital and en route care providers, particularly in combat and traumatic injury settings.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the long-term safety and effectiveness of UC-MSC treatment for severe COVID-19 patients, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found UC-MSC treatment improved lung lesion recovery and reduced symptoms in COVID-19 patients, but did not assess Walking.
population_specificity: Severe COVID-19 patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effects of ERAS-based home exercise pre-rehabilitation, including walking, on body function and postoperative outcomes in ESRD patients awaiting kidney transplantation.
results_summary: The study assessed improvements in physical function (e.g., 6-minute walking test, gait speed) and secondary outcomes like hospitalization duration, complications, and quality of life, but results were not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 47 ESRD patients awaiting kidney transplantation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (personalized family exercise program including aerobic exercise, functional resistance exercise, and flexibility training).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated (outcomes measured before/after intervention, before discharge, and 1 month post-discharge).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the diagnostic process in Psychiatry through a phenomenological perspective, identifying four core concepts related to clinical encounters.
results_summary: The study identified four phenomenological concepts ("tightrope walking," "holistic experience," "co-construction of symptoms," and "evolving typification") to enhance psychiatric diagnosis, supported by clinical case extracts.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on theoretical psychiatric diagnosis concepts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of lipoic acid (LA) supplementation on multiple sclerosis (MS), including its pharmacokinetics, efficacy, safety, and mechanisms, through a systematic review of in vitro, in vivo, and clinical studies.
results_summary: LA showed anti-inflammatory and antioxidative effects in cell and mouse models of MS, reducing immune cell infiltration and clinical disability scores. In MS patients, LA administration was associated with stable disability scores and improved walking performance with few adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and cell/mouse models of MS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pelvic movements in a robotic gait training system on gait rehabilitation outcomes in stroke patients with hemiparesis.
results_summary: The study found that gait training with pelvic movements significantly increased stride length, cadence, and walking speed in stroke patients, along with enhanced muscle activation in key lower limb muscles during the stance phase. The pelvis-on group showed greater improvements in EMG signals for gluteus medius, biceps femoris, and gastrocnemius muscles compared to the pelvis-off group.
population_specificity: Twenty-four stroke patients with hemiparesis (23 completed the study).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of gait training with or without pelvic movements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic effects of implantable functional electrical stimulation on gait performance in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Preliminary evidence suggests functional electrical stimulation may improve walking endurance, speed, ankle mobility, and push-off force in stroke survivors, but study heterogeneity, small sample sizes, and lack of randomized controlled trials limit conclusive findings.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of wearable GPS and accelerometers for monitoring mobility and physical activity in patients with neurodegenerative disorders (NDDs).
results_summary: The study found that wearable GPS and accelerometers offer a cost-effective, noninvasive method to monitor mobility and physical activity in NDD patients, with potential as biomarkers for disease progression and treatment response. Accelerometers were widely used, while GPS-derived measures showed promise but required further validation.
population_specificity: Patients with common neurodegenerative disorders (Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, motor neuron diseases/amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, vascular parkinsonism, and vascular dementia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of repeated co-injections of corticosteroids plus hyaluronic acid (HA) versus HA injections alone in improving pain, physical function, and physical functional performance in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both groups showed reduced pain and improved physical function over time, but the corticosteroids plus HA group demonstrated significantly better outcomes in WOMAC-pain, physical function, chair-rising time, and KOOS-pain from 1 week through 6 months posttreatment.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence score of 2 or 3)
effective_dosage: Injections administered once a week for 3 consecutive weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early short-term exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation (CR) following pacemaker (PM) implantation improves physical function and quality of life (QOL).
results_summary: Both groups showed improved 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), but only the CR group demonstrated significant improvements in QOL subscales (vitality and mental health). No procedure-related complications were observed.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular diseases who underwent PM implantation and had a 6MWD of less than 85% of the predicted value.
effective_dosage: Individualized exercise-based training with moderate intensity (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether trimetazidine could improve exercise endurance (measured by 6-MWT), life quality, and heart function in non-ischemic HF patients.
results_summary: Trimetazidine significantly improved the 6-minute walking test (6-MWT) with a weighted mean difference of 48.51 meters, indicating enhanced exercise endurance in non-ischemic HF patients. Secondary outcomes like life quality scores and echocardiography parameters were also evaluated, but detailed results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Non-ischemic heart failure patients aged ≥18 years.
study_duration: Follow-up period was longer than three months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess global function and survival factors in patients with surgically managed peripheral and spinal bone metastases, focusing on pain relief, walking ability, and upper-limb function.
results_summary: Walking improved in 57% of patients (49/86), alongside pain relief and maintained autonomy, though functional improvements were modest. Median survival varied by primary cancer type, with breast and thyroid cancers showing longer survival.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral or spinal bone metastases from osteophilic cancers (lung, prostate, kidney, breast, thyroid), mean age 62.6–66.4 years, 54% female.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current practices in neuro-orthopedic surgery for treating spastic equinovarus foot in adults, focusing on patient assessment, treatment choice, procedures, and outcomes.
results_summary: Neuro-orthopedic procedures (e.g., neurotomy, tendon lengthening) reduced impairments (spasticity, range of motion, foot position) and improved gait and walking function, but their impact on participation and personalized goals remains unclear. Practice is heterogeneous, with no consensus on pre-, intra-, and post-surgical strategies.
population_specificity: Adults with spastic equinovarus foot.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether VR-based lung rehabilitation training combined with health education could improve lung function, walking distance, and cognitive function in elderly patients with COPD and mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study group showed improved lung function (FEV percentage), increased 6-minute walking distance, and better cognitive scores (MoCA) compared to the control group after 12 weeks of training.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with COPD and mild cognitive impairment (60 participants, 50 per group after randomization).
effective_dosage: Not specified (routine lung rehabilitation training vs. VR-based training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effectiveness of an individually tailored mobile health exercise intervention (EXCAP) in preventing physical function decline and improving symptoms in older adults with myeloid neoplasms receiving outpatient chemotherapy.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that the EXCAP intervention is being studied as a model for improving physical function and symptoms in vulnerable older patients undergoing cancer treatments, but specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Older adults with myeloid neoplasms receiving outpatient chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health effects of Baduanjin exercise on physical function, walking ability, balance, and anxiety in adults aged 65 years and older.
results_summary: The study found significant benefits of Baduanjin on physical function, walking ability, balance, and anxiety, as well as improvements in quality of life and reductions in falls and pain. However, conclusions were limited due to the lack of rigorous studies outside mainland China.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65 years and older from mainland China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of exercise, including walking, as a non-pharmacological treatment for managing symptoms and potentially reducing disease progression in multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that exercise is safe and effective for improving symptoms of multiple sclerosis, with evidence suggesting it may also help reduce disease progression. The abstract highlights the importance of clinical guidelines and behavior change strategies to promote exercise in MS patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop exercise intensity targets for prescribing and progressing walking therapy in individuals with varying levels of walking impairment after stroke.
results_summary: The study found that step number increased by 73 steps per session, with baseline walking speed predicting an additional 302 steps per 0.1 m/s increase. Aerobic minutes increased by 0.56 minutes per session, while age predicted a decrease of 0.39 minutes per year.
population_specificity: Twenty-five individuals in inpatient rehabilitation after stroke.
effective_dosage: Twenty monitored one-hour physical therapy sessions.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but 500 sessions were monitored across participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HFNC-aided supplemental oxygen during a 6-minute walk test would improve self-paced exercise performance and cardiopulmonary outcomes in patients with stable COPD.
results_summary: HFNC-aided walking resulted in a longer walking distance and lower energy expenditure index compared to unaided walking, but no differences were observed in transcutaneous carbon dioxide tension or self-reported dyspnea scores.
population_specificity: 30 stable COPD patients without disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Botulinum Neurotoxin Type A (BoNT-A) influences muscle fibroadipose degeneration in stroke survivors with equinovarus foot and how spasticity and walking capability affect muscle ultrasonographic characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that BoNT-A does not appear to influence muscle degeneration, and muscle alterations depend on spasticity severity and walking capability rather than BoNT-A treatment. Differences in muscle characteristics between the medial gastrocnemius and soleus were observed, particularly in patients with preserved function or severe spasticity.
population_specificity: 53 stroke survivors with equinovarus foot and spasticity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of acupotomy combined with acupuncture and interferential current therapy for treating lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial, and results are not yet available as it is ongoing. The primary and secondary outcomes will assess pain, walking distance, disability, and pain questionnaire scores.
population_specificity: Forty participants diagnosed with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
effective_dosage: Acupuncture and interferential current therapy twice a week for 8 weeks; experimental group receives additional acupotomy once a week for 8 weeks.
study_duration: 8 weeks of treatment with a 4-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate and improve the modified Erasmus GBS Outcome Score (mEGOS) for predicting walking inability in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) patients across different regions.
results_summary: The mEGOS was validated in an international cohort, showing good predictive accuracy (AUC >0.7) for walking inability at 4 and 26 weeks. Recalibration improved model accuracy, and a region-specific version (mEGOS-Eu/NA) was developed for Europe/North America.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥6 years with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) unable to walk independently, from Europe/North America, Asia, and other regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validation of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) in people with symptomatic, nonlimb-threatening peripheral artery disease to assess their effectiveness in measuring disease and treatment impacts on patient well-being.
results_summary: The review identified 24 PROMs, with 8 of 15 disease-specific PROMs showing excellent reliability (Cronbach alpha ≥0.80) and 6 demonstrating excellent sensitivity to change. The peripheral artery questionnaire, vascular quality of life questionnaire, and walking impairment questionnaire met full validation criteria, while the European Quality of Life 5-Dimension and SF-36 were the most validated generic PROMs.
population_specificity: People with symptomatic, nonlimb-threatening peripheral artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the reliability of assessment tests for body structure, function, and activity (including walking and mobility) in older adults with dementia.
results_summary: The study found high to very high relative reliability for walking and mobility tests, indicating good reproducibility. However, substantial changes were needed to confirm real improvements in absolute reliability measures.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between cognitive, psychological, and physical function and depressive symptoms in people with mild-moderate cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found that depressive symptoms were associated with poorer balance, slower gait speed, higher anxiety, concern about falling, and reduced quality of life in individuals with cognitive impairment. These relationships persisted even after adjusting for comorbidities and previous falls.
population_specificity: 309 participants with mild-moderate cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dietary weight loss combined with either aerobic exercise (walking), a "move more, more often" approach (SitLess), or both, on weight loss and maintenance in older adults with obesity.
results_summary: All groups achieved significant weight loss over 6 months, with no differences between them. The SitLess approach improved total activity time, while aerobic exercise improved moderate-to-vigorous activity time. During maintenance, the aerobic exercise group regained more weight than the SitLess group.
population_specificity: Low-active older adults (age 65-86 years) with obesity.
effective_dosage: EX participants aimed for 150 minutes of walking per week; SL participants targeted frequent movement throughout the day (step goal not specified).
study_duration: 6-month intervention followed by a 12-month maintenance period (total 18 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize foot conditions and associated interventions among homeless persons, including issues related to walking.
results_summary: The study found that foot problems, including functional limitations with walking, were highly prevalent among homeless individuals, with inadequate foot hygiene and improperly-fitting shoes being common issues.
population_specificity: Homeless individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise, particularly home-based aerobic walking programs, improves sleep outcomes in cancer patients.
results_summary: The qualitative review suggested a beneficial effect of exercise on sleep in some studies (48%), but the meta-analysis of RCTs found no significant effect on subjective or objective sleep measures, possibly due to a floor effect.
population_specificity: Cancer patients, with breast cancer patients being the most represented subgroup.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance training or Nordic walking influences humanin (HN) protein levels in skeletal muscle and serum in prediabetic males.
results_summary: Resistance training increased skeletal muscle HN protein levels by 35%, but no changes were observed in serum HN levels. There was a correlation between serum HN levels and improved glucose tolerance in the resistance training group.
population_specificity: Male subjects (n=55) with impaired glucose regulation (prediabetes).
effective_dosage: Exercise interventions (resistance training or Nordic walking) were performed three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the feasibility of using wearable accelerometers to assess gait parameters in people with Multiple Sclerosis (pwMS) and correlate these with patient-reported outcomes.
results_summary: Gait parameters were significantly modified in pwMS with higher disability, showing moderate to high correlations with patient-reported walking impact. Wearable accelerometers were found useful for assessing gait performance in clinical settings, especially for mild to moderate disability.
population_specificity: 105 people with Multiple Sclerosis (EDSS 0-6.5) and 47 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the effects of treadmill walking exercises on bone mineral status and inflammatory cytokines in obese asthmatic patients treated with long-term corticosteroids.
results_summary: Treadmill walking significantly increased bone mineral density, serum calcium, and HDL-c while reducing inflammatory cytokines, blood lipids, and BMI in obese asthmatic patients, with no significant changes in the control group.
population_specificity: Obese asthmatic patients (both sexes, aged 41-53) on long-term corticosteroid treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (aerobic exercise training on treadmill).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an intervention to optimize pain management on pain intensity and pain interference with function, specifically in the domain of walking, among nursing home residents.
results_summary: The intervention did not achieve its primary objective of reducing mean pain intensity by 2 points, but marginal reductions in pain were observed at 6-month follow-up. The intervention and control groups differed significantly in the intensity sum score and in the domain of walking, with a decrease in the proportion of respondents reporting pain scores >0.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents in Germany affected by chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of physeal osteotomy for acute valgus correction in adolescent Morquio-A patients with severe knee deformity.
results_summary: The study found that physeal osteotomy achieved significant acute valgus correction (average 39 degrees) and improved intermalleolar distance, with no loss of ambulatory status. However, none of the patients completed the 6-minute walking test at follow-up, indicating persistent functional limitations.
population_specificity: Adolescent Morquio-A patients (ages 10-14) with severe valgus knee deformity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and optimal conditions for using SpinalonTM (a combination of levodopa/carbidopa/buspirone) to induce reflex walking in paraplegic animals and spinal cord-injured subjects.
results_summary: The study found that SpinalonTM triggered 45-minute episodes of reflex walking in paraplegic animals and improved performance over time with musculoskeletal and cardiovascular benefits. A phase I/IIa study identified the maximal tolerated dose, and a phase IIb study explored efficacy optimization using additional devices like treadmills and spinal cord stimulators.
population_specificity: Spinal cord-injured subjects (45 in phase I/IIa, 150 in phase IIb).
effective_dosage: Maximal tolerated dose identified (specific amount not stated).
study_duration: Daily administration for one month in animals; human study durations not specified.

study_goal: The study does not address Walking; it focuses on the treatment of mantle cell lymphoma with ibrutinib.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to Walking.
population_specificity: A 74-year-old male patient with stage 3 mantle cell lymphoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if individuals within 31 days of stroke onset could produce controlled lower limb movement and phasic muscle activity during Upright Pedalling (UP), despite severe paresis and inability to walk.
results_summary: Participants with severe to moderate lower limb paresis demonstrated smooth pedalling during UP, with varied muscle activation patterns in both affected and unaffected legs, suggesting potential for controlled movement early post-stroke.
population_specificity: Eight adults 3-30 days post-stroke, with unilateral lower limb paresis and inability to walk without assistance.
effective_dosage: One one-minute session of UP at comfortable cadence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a personalized walking exercise program managed by dialysis staff improves functional status and quality of life in adult dialysis patients.
results_summary: The study assessed changes in physical performance (via 6-minute walking test and sit-to-stand test) and quality of life (via KDQOL-SF questionnaire) but did not report specific outcomes in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Adult patients on dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy and safety of Buzhong Yiqi Tang (BZYQT) for stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that BZYQT improved clinical symptoms, exercise capacity, lung function, and quality of life in patients with stable COPD, with an excellent safety profile. However, the abstract does not mention Walking.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with stable COPD according to Chinese Medical Association or GOLD guidelines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether diabetes mellitus (DM) negatively impacts the response to supervised exercise therapy (SET) in patients with intermittent claudication, specifically focusing on walking distance outcomes.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with one study showing significantly better walking distance improvements in non-DM patients, another showing no significant improvement in DM patients, and the largest study finding no adverse effect of DM on walking distance after SET. The data were inadequate to conclusively determine if DM impairs the exercise response.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication, some with diabetes mellitus (DM).
